title: Glasgow UCI Cycling World Championships 2023: Key information
content:
Cyclist
Glasgow UCI Cycling World Championships 2023: Key information

The 2023 UCI Cycling World Championships will be held in Glasgow, Scotland from Thursday 3rd August to Sunday 13th August. It marks the first time that most cycling disciplines will feature in the same event, with these combined UCI Cycling World Championships scheduled every four years. The next will take place in the Haute-Savoie region of France in 2027.

A total of 200 rainbow jerseys will be awarded across the following events: Road, Para-cycling Road, Track, Para-cycling Track, MTB Cross-country, MTB Downhill, MTB Marathon, BMX Racing, BMX Freestyle Park, BMX Freestyle Flatland, Trials, Indoor Cycling and Gran Fondo. The only disciplines not included are cyclocross and gravel, the former being a winter sport and the latter only being introduced after these Worlds were organised.

Last year, Remco Evenepoel (Belgium) and Annemiek van Vleuten (Netherlands) won the elite road races, with Tobias Foss (Norway) and Ellen van Dijk (Netherlands) riding their way to glory in the time-trial.

Glasgow UCI Cycling World Championships 2023: Key information

Dates: Thursday 3rd August to Sunday 13th August 2023
Location: Glasgow and across Scotland (Dumfries & Galloway, Dundee & Angus, Edinburgh, Fort William, Loch Lomond, Perth & Kinross, Stirling, Tweed Valley)
Television coverage: BBC, FloSports, France TV, ESPN, Eurosport/GCN, NOS

Glasgow UCI World Championships 2023: Road route maps and profiles

Junior Women

Road race

The Women’s Junior Road Race is a 70km course departing at 10am on Saturday 5th August, completing five laps of a 11.3km circuit around Glasgow with a QoM point at Montrose Street.

Junior Men

Road race

The Men’s Junior Road Race is a 127.2km course departing at 1pm on Saturday 5th August. Rides will begin with a climb on Montrose Street then undertake nine laps of the 11.3km circuit.

Elite Men

Road race

On Sunday 6th August, the 271.1km Elite Men’s Road Race will depart from Edinburgh, heading over two KoM points and 3570m of elevation before completing ten laps of the Glasgow circuit.

Mixed Relay team time-trial

Introduced into the UCI Road World Championships from 2019 in Yorkshire, the team time-trial mixed relay has been won by the Netherlands, Germany and Switzerland. Teams of six riders are broken down into three men and three women. For 2023, the men will complete 20.15km before handing over the waiting three women, who will ride the final 20.15km for a total of 40.3km and elevation gain of 484m.

U23 Men

Individual Time-Trial

The ITT events will take place in and around Stirling. The U23 Men will cover 35.2km.

Junior Women

Individual Time-Trial

A 13.4km ITT course awaits for the Junior Women.

Elite Women

Individual Time-Trial

The Elite Women’s field will face a 36.3km ITT.

Junior Men

Individual Time-Trial

For the Junior Men, the ITT will be 22.8km.

Elite Men

Individual Time-Trial

Travelling the furthest west before snapping back east, the Elite Men’s ITT will be 47.8km.

U23 Men

Road Race

From the beauty of Loch Lomond and with 2,436m elevation before hitting 7 laps of the Glasgow circuit, the U23 Men’s Road Race will be 168.4km.

Elite Women/U23 Women

Road Race

Both the Elite Women and U23 Women’s Road Race will again be the same race at 154.1km, with standalone events meant to be implemented in 2025.

Glasgow UCI World Championships 2023: How to watch

BBC Sport has secured full broadcasting rights across Great Britain to the 2023 UCI Cycling World Championships.

A full list of broadcasters will be updated, but unlikely to deviate much from the following:

Full list of broadcasters

Australia: Stan and Nine
Belgium: RTBF, VRT

Third: Michael Matthews
